title: 111_s3988
content: The "Spending Control Act of 2010" establishes the independent "Grace Commission II" to conduct reviews and submit reports. The "Grace Commission II" is composed of eight members appointed by the President with Senate approval. Nominations must be submitted within 180 days of the Act's enactment, with consultations required with various congressional leaders for selecting appointees. The "Grace Commission II" consists of eight members appointed by the President with Senate approval. Each member serves for life, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and the Chairman is designated by the President. Members are paid based on the Executive Schedule. The "Grace Commission II" consists of eight members appointed by the President with Senate approval, serving for life. The Chairman is designated by the President. Members are paid based on the Executive Schedule, including travel expenses and per diem. The "Grace Commission II" consists of eight members appointed by the President with Senate approval, serving for life. Members who are federal employees or Members of Congress cannot receive additional compensation. Five members constitute a quorum for meetings called by the Chairman. SEC. 5. DIRECTOR; STAFF; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Commission, paid at level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Director may appoint staff with approval, without following certain civil service laws. Staff may be paid without regard to certain provisions of title 5, United States Code. The Commission may appoint individuals at GS-18 pay rate. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Commission can hire experts and consultants through contracts. The Commission has powers to appoint individuals at GS-18 pay rate, detail personnel from federal agencies, and hire experts and consultants through contracts. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, administer oaths, and obtain necessary information from government agencies to carry out its duties under the Act. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and the Commission can use the United States mails like other government agencies. The Commission can request administrative support services from the General Services Administration and may also contract with government and private agencies for necessary products and services to fulfill its responsibilities under the Act. SEC. 7. COST CONTROL REVIEWS. The Commission conducts biennial reviews of cost control in the Federal Government, focusing on improving management and reducing costs. They conduct in-depth studies of Executive agencies to evaluate potential operational improvements and develop recommendations for increased efficiency, enhanced managerial accountability, and improved administrative control. Opportunities for managerial improvements in the short- and long-term, areas for further study to justify potential savings, and ways to reduce governmental expenditures, indebtedness, and improve personnel management. SEC. 8. REPORTS. The Commission is required to submit interim reports containing preliminary results 180 days before the final report, and final reports every two years with detailed findings, conclusions, and recommendations to Congress and the President. The Commission must submit final reports every two years with detailed findings, conclusions, and recommendations to Congress and the President. The final report should also include proposed legislation in the form of an implementation bill to carry out recommendations, but only if agreed upon by at least five members of the Commission. SEC. 9. CONGRESSIONAL CONSIDERATION OF PROPOSED LEGISLATION. Upon submission of a final report to Congress under section 8(b), the implementation bill is introduced in both the Senate and the House of Representatives by designated members or leaders. Members of the House of Representatives designated by the majority and minority leaders introduce an implementation bill, which is then referred to the appropriate committees in the Senate and House. If a committee fails to report the bill within 15 days, they are discharged from further consideration. Upon being reported or discharged from the committee, an implementation bill shall be placed on the appropriate calendar for floor consideration. Any Member of the respective House can move to proceed to the consideration of the bill, with all points of order waived. The motion is privileged and not debatable. The implementation bill is privileged in the Senate, not debatable, and not subject to amendment. If a motion to proceed is agreed to, the bill remains unfinished business. The bill may not be amended in the Senate or House of Representatives. Debate is limited to 10 hours, divided equally between supporters and opponents. The implementation bill is privileged in the Senate, not debatable, and not subject to amendment. Debate is limited to 10 hours, equally divided between supporters and opponents. A motion to limit debate is in order. A motion to reconsider the vote on the bill is not allowed. Vote on final passage occurs after debate. Chair's rulings on procedure can be appealed. Decisions of the Chair on rules for implementation bills are made without debate. If one House receives an implementation bill from the other House, it is not referred to a committee. The receiving House follows its usual procedure, as if it had not received the bill from the other House. The rules for implementation bills are decided by the Chair without debate. If one House receives a bill from the other House, it is not sent to a committee but follows its usual procedure. This section is enacted by Congress as part of the rules of each House, applicable only to the procedure for implementation bills. It recognizes the constitutional right of each House to change its rules regarding procedures. The rules for implementation bills are decided by the Chair without debate, applicable only to the procedure for implementation bills. The Commission will terminate one day after submitting its third final report. Definitions in the Act include "calendar day," "Commission," "implementation bill," and "member."
